6.92.text: More and more magic city dwellers

8.76.text: are hitting the pavement with two wheels these days

13.54.text: Here's some of the top ways

14.98.text: you can be safe as you bike.

19.91.text: a good bike check is in order.

24.16.text: Make sure your front and rear lights are working

26.32.text: and are able to be seen by those around you.

28.74.text: If you have them on but they are being blocked by a bag

31.36.text: then they won't really do you any good.

34.44.text: Check that your tires are pumped to the correct air pressure.

37.84.text: You can find out how much pressure your tires require

40.62.text: by reading the information on the sidewall of your tire.

46.65.text: Brakes should be free from the tire when disengaged

49.49.text: and have a tight grip when engaged.

53.24.text: Give your pedal a little kick before your ride

56.73.text: The chain should move smoothly over the gears.

61.12.text: These are the levers that lock your tire in place.

64.32.text: Make sure they are closed and tight.

79.06.text: If you have a drivers liscence

80.78.text: then you already know the rules of the road when cycling

83.36.text: because the rules are the same.

86.08.text: You're a vehicle too, so you should...

92.30.text: and don't ride on the sidewalk.

100.45.text: Use hand signals to tell drivers where you're heading.

103.69.text: When signaling use your left hand to signal left

107.39.text: your right hand to signal right

109.83.text: and your left hand down to signal stop.

112.96.text: To change lanes look over your shoulder multiple times

115.84.text: to make sure your path is clear.

118.02.text: Signal and move into the lane smoothly and deliberately.

128.96.text: and keep your eyes peeled for danger.

132.69.text: Anticipate what drivers, pedestrians, and other cyclists might do next.

136.91.text: Watch for turning vehicles and look out for debris,

142.18.text: You can even practice dodging obstacles with items from home.

152.81.text: and when you have to drive in those places

158.36.text: The door zone is an area just outside parallel parked cars.

162.31.text: When riding in the door zone

164.15.text: you run the risk of a door being opened

169.38.text: To ride safely next to parallel parked vehicles

172.16.text: move out of the door zone

173.68.text: and don't be afraid to take the lane.

175.78.text: Now that you know how to keep yourself safe on the bike

178.78.text: make sure you keep your bike safe too.

181.30.text: always lock your bike when you leave it unattended.

183.84.text:
A U-lock and cable together make the
most secure combination,

187.68.text: but either one is better than none.

190.04.text: Don't secure your bike to hand rails

192.04.text: because you may cause accessibility issues for others.

196.29.text: you won't make friends that way.

198.68.text: Attaching your bike to the bus

201.40.text: lower the bike rack on the front of the bus

205.64.text: put your bike on the rack

207.42.text: placing your front wheel on the side

210.98.text: Pull the arm out and raise it to the top of your tire.

214.43.text: Once you release the arm it should retract

216.39.text: and fit securely to your tire.

223.33.text: Alright riders you're ready to go.
